instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Hello,

I have a touchbar mac that does not output to the internal display. I can get video output via USB C, and the logic board powers on and boots mac os.
The history is liquid damage, no obvious corrosion except between pins 1 and 43 of J8500. Cleaned up and replaced LCD cable, verified no connection, but the problem still persists.
I've been troubleshooting this one for a while but have come up pretty much empty handed.

Originally I thought there was a good chance that <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> was dead (the short might have sent backlight voltage to the chip), so I did some research and found a replacement for the CBTL06142EEE (I could not find it available for order) with a HD3SS212ZQET, which should be compatible. The system sill powers on but it still has no display.

I get <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_EN</SIGNAL> ad 3.3V.

<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> appears at 3.4 volts and disappears a second after power on. Same for <SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PANEL_FET_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> .

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is .01 volts (almost nothing)

<SIGNAL>PANEL_P5V_EN_D</SIGNAL> is 0 volts.

Can anyone with a little more experience with the newer macs assist in troubleshooting? I'd really appreciate it.

Thanks,

Stefan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
I think <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is the closest schematic/boardview for your board.
In this case, GMUX <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> is fried...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
I have been working off of <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> for lack of the exact schematic.
I actually did replace <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> with the TI chip I was able to get my hands on. It is supposedly compatible, and the datasheets seem to agree with that. No change, however.

Tested with a display that was previously working.

EDIT - I verified pinout functionality between the two chips.

Down at the bottom of this page in the section for apple gmux was the only clue I could find about a compatible replacement (had a hard time finding CBTL06142EEE):
[url]https://people.freedesktop.org/~narmstrong/<SIGNAL>MESON_DRM_DOC</SIGNAL>/gpu/vga-switcheroo.html[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: GMUX is supposed to have firmware...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Hmm.. source? I read the datasheet, and my admittedly poor understanding of the chip design makes me think that it is just a high speed capable switch, and it's outside behavior is controlled by the <SIGNAL>DX_SEL</SIGNAL> pin on the chip.
Or do you mean that the system firmware has to have the proper GMUX chip specified in it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: So... long shot but does anyone have any ideas? Customer just asked if he can send it to rossmann's in NY, and I am going to have to make it someone elses problem ( out of my control, he asked me)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: Get GMUX from same donor board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Sounds like I should have done that in the first place. As always, thank you for taking time to reply.
Don't have time to get a donor, had this far too long anyway and I think the customer is done with us.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Apple is actually trying to make the repair as more dificil possible.
Even charger chips have firmware.
So be aware and replace any chips susceptible to have firmware only with chips removed from identical donor board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
[QUOTE="iambehr, post: 39757"]Hmm.. source? I read the datasheet, and my admittedly poor understanding of the chip design makes me think that it is just a high speed capable switch, and it's outside behavior is controlled by the <SIGNAL>DX_SEL</SIGNAL> pin on the chip.
Or do you mean that the system firmware has to have the proper GMUX chip specified in it?[/QUOTE]

I have a 00281 with this issue. Tried a to replace <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no change in symtoms. Ive now pulled the MUX chip of a scrap 00928 and will get back to you with results

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Thanks! It will be interesting to hear what happens.

(reason for edit: mixed up customers and said something that was not correct)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: I Put a <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> from another 15 touchbar and still have no internal display. I will do some more digging and swap some more parts out until it works

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: Don't waste time, if you can't get GMUX from the same board model...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 40002"]Don't waste time, if you can't get GMUX from the same board model...[/QUOTE]

<CHIP>U9850</CHIP> is not the commonly known programmed GMUX. I pulled from the same model anyway. That is not the only thing failing on these boards when those lines short.
